narrative.title: NIH Data Management and Sharing Plan

question.text: Types and amount of scientific data expected to be generated in the project

json.answer: This study on autism and social communication will generate multi-modal datasets from youth participants, including demographic and clinical datasets, behavioral and cognitive assessments, neuroimaging and/or physiological measures, derived variables, and associated documentation such as protocols, data dictionary, and README files. The estimated amount of scientific data is substantial, with the largest portion being neurobiological data.

question.text: Scientific data that will be preserved and shared, and the rationale for doing so

json.answer: All collected data types will be preserved and shared through the NIMH Data Archive (NDA) to facilitate future research on autism and social communication. The rationale for sharing these data is to enable other researchers to replicate findings, explore new hypotheses, and accelerate the discovery of effective interventions for individuals with autism.

question.text: Metadata, other relevant data, and associated documentation

json.answer: To facilitate interpretation of the scientific data, we will make accessible a data dictionary that defines all variables, protocols for treatment and assessment, data collection instruments, and a README file explaining the structure and content of the shared datasets. These metadata and documentation will be submitted to the NDA alongside the primary data.

section.title: Element 2: Related Tools, Software and/or Code

question.text: Element 2: Related Tools, Software and/or Code

json.answer: Specialized tools and software may be needed to access or manipulate certain types of shared scientific data, such as neuroimaging data which might require FSL or AFNI for analysis. These tools are widely available in the research community, and their use will be documented in the data dictionary and README files accompanying the datasets.

To enable interoperability of datasets and resources, we will apply common data standards recommended by the NIMH Data Archive (NDA) for each data type. For example, neuroimaging data will adhere to the BIDS standard, while demographic and clinical datasets will follow the guidelines outlined in the NDA's Data Dictionary. These standards ensure that our datasets can be easily combined with others for meta-analyses and comparative studies.

section.title: Element 4: Data Preservation, Access, and Associated Timelines

question.text: Repository where scientific data and metadata will be archived

json.answer: The scientific data and associated metadata from this project will be archived in the NIMH Data Archive (NDA), a repository specifically designed for storing and sharing human subjects data related to mental health research.

question.text: How scientific data will be findable and identifiable

json.answer: Each dataset will be assigned a unique identifier by the NDA, allowing it to be easily searchable and accessible through the NDA's web interface. Additionally, we will use standard indexing tools like DOI (Digital Object Identifier) for datasets and publications to enhance discoverability.

question.text: When and how long the scientific data will be made available

json.answer: The scientific data will be made available no later than the time of publication of the main findings or at the end of the performance period, whichever comes first. The data will remain available indefinitely through the NDA, subject to any limitations imposed by informed consent or confidentiality agreements.

section.title: Element 5: Access, Distribution, or Reuse Considerations

question.text: Factors affecting subsequent access, distribution, or reuse of scientific data

json.answer: Given that this project involves human subjects and is conducted under IRB approval with broad data sharing consent/assent obtained as appropriate, we anticipate few limitations on data sharing. However, any restrictions related to protecting participant privacy, rights, and confidentiality will be clearly documented in the data dictionary and README files accompanying the shared datasets.

question.text: Whether access to scientific data will be controlled

json.answer: Access to the scientific data will be controlled through the NDA's system for managing permissions and access requests. Researchers wishing to access our datasets will need to register with the NDA, agree to its terms of use, and in some cases, obtain approval from us or the NDA.

question.text: Protections for privacy, rights, and confidentiality of human research participants

json.answer: To protect participant privacy, all shared data will be de-identified. This includes removing direct identifiers (e.g., names, addresses) and applying methods to prevent re-identification through combinations of indirect identifiers. We will also adhere to the terms of the Certificate of Confidentiality issued for this study, which further protects against disclosure of identifiable information.

section.title: Element 6: Oversight of Data Management and Sharing

question.text: Element 6: Oversight of Data Management and Sharing

json.answer: Compliance with this Data Management and Sharing Plan will be monitored and managed by the Principal Investigators (PIs) of the project. The PIs are responsible for ensuring that all aspects of data management, including data collection, storage, sharing, and protection of human subjects' privacy, are conducted according to the plan outlined here and in accordance with relevant regulations and guidelines from the NIH and our institution's IRB. Regular oversight will include periodic review of data sharing activities, updates to the data dictionary and documentation as necessary, and reporting any changes or issues to the funding agency as required.
